Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 10:33AM digger wrote: I've got Dr. Mehrara as my PS as well.  I've got Dr. Monica Morrow as my breast surgeon, and she works closely with Dr. Mehrara.  So far, so good with both of them.  I'm hopefully through my tissue expansion stage (will find out for sure on Monday) then my exchange is scheduled for 3/17.  I have found MSK to be very professional and exceedingly well-organized, although it does feel like a factory at times.  Nevertheless, I wanted to go somewhere where they had done tons and tons of these procedures, so I'm willing to put up with the factory-like experience.  Dr. Morrow is going to follow me from now on, breast cancer-wise, but I do wish I had an oncologist.  She's a surgeon, so she doesn't really deal with the other treatments that much.  I only had DCIS, but still, I'd like to have a medical oncologist at one point.
Posts.Title: MSK Oncologists elizzim pdlc436

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 11:04AM digger wrote: Yep, after all of the reconstruction is over, I'll do that.
Posts.Title: MSK Oncologists elizzim pdlc436

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 01:02PM digger wrote: Wow, I haven't heard Dr. Gaynor's name for a long time.  When I was pregnant with my twins sixteen years ago, I saw Dr. Gaynor for a while because I've got a blood clotting disorder, and he's a hematologist.  I didn't realize he was also an oncologist, but I guess that makes sense.  He was fine back then, and I guess he's embracing alternative therapy now as well, which is great.
Posts.Title: MSK Oncologists elizzim pdlc436

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 09:17PM digger wrote: Just wanted to let you know I'm going through the same thing, and it's such a bummer.  I'm sorry you have to go through this and just try to keep your spirits up.
Posts.Title: One more question... Yellow pus coming from incision? Michelle820 Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 03:28PM digger wrote: No pain here either with getting the drains out.  I was so excited that when I was able to get one of the two drains out, they let me pick which one (it's funny what bc does to you when that's your excitement for the day!).  I had one wrapped around my chest and then sticking into the armpit, and I was so thrilled to get it out, really no pain.  The anticipation of pain is what will do you in, but just take a deep breath, and you'll be perfectly fine.
Posts.Title: Getting the drains out robinri CathyMcD

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 12:19PM digger wrote: Make sure the drains aren't plugged (did they show you how to strip the tubing?), but in my case, I hardly had any drainage after four days as well.  I got mine out (both) on day 6.
Posts.Title: Getting the drains out robinri CathyMcD

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 12:55PM digger wrote: I had a left total mastectomy with tissue expander placement on Nov 20.  I am incredibly squeamish when it comes to blood, gore, you name it, and that's been a real problem in the past with two boys!  Anyway, I had absolutely no intention of looking at my scar for a good long time, but, as fate would have it, the incision became infected and then I had to expose myself to it numerous times each day to help with the healing.  I think that, the first time you look at your scar, it's easier to look in the mirror at your reflection first.  I read that somewhere in some book before my surgery, so that's what I did, and so it worked out okay with me.  I guess by looking at the mirror first, it almost seems as if it's someone else staring back at you.  Now, about seven weeks out and with a scar that's still in the process of healing, I can say it's really okay, and I know you'll be okay.
Posts.Title: January Mastectomy crusader1 bettelou68

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 03:40PM digger wrote: I vote to go for it; you're worth it!  I stayed in one of the "luxury" suites at MSK when I had my mastectomy last year.  It was expensive, but well worth it.  My husband was able to spend each evening with me on his own recliner/sofa bed, and the nurse was available whenever I needed her.  It was also super quiet and peaceful.  I had my own shower/bathroom, which was nice.  When I had to be re-admitted for an infection a week later, I stayed on one of the regular MSK floors.  My roommate was an elderly woman who coughed and snored all night when she wasn't on the phone.  I couldn't wait to get out of there.
Posts.Title: Luxury suite anyone? NancyD cakeisgreat

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 03:08PM digger wrote: Thanks for everyone's help.  I decided that I would take people's advice and call the PS's office so I didn't have to obsess about this all weekend.  I do have an appt on Monday for my first fill, but I'm glad I called this afternoon.  I think, upon describing the incision to the nurse, that it's okay, it's just the scabbing coming off, and I guess I'm just a "bruiser."   For some reason, even though no one else can see the scar underneath my clothes (my husband won't look at it either), I just feel so ugly and it's carrying into my mood that I present to the outside world.  If I look so ugly on the inside, how could anyone be even remotely attracted to me?  They must be so repulsed by me.  Also, everyone is so happy that I'm now officially "cancer-free."  My only feeling is that the operation may have been a success, but they killed the patient, if you know what I mean.  I should be happy, I know, but I feel like some ugly monster.
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 03:32PM digger wrote: It's likely osteopenia that your doctor was talking about...that's a highly curable stage before osteoporosis.  Dietary and exercise changes can really help with osteopenia, and in fact, can pretty much prevent the more serious osteoporosis. I know I'm going to get slammed as well, but I think perhaps you should consider letting yourself move on until there is a clear answer, and at some point, you may just have to come to the conclusion that there never will be an answer.  Sometimes, things just happen and there really is no explanation.  Also, I can't imagine all the radiation exposure from all the testing is good for you.  I don't think the doctors are doing all of this for money...I would try to step away for a bit and perhaps look at your perspective....is it the doctors who just won't let these things go, or is there a part of you that doesn't want to hear what they're saying?   Take care of yourself.
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: digger wrote: I am 15 days post left breast mx with expander placement.  About 6 days after surgery, I was back in the hospital with an infection and IV antibiotics then sent home with a stronger antibiotic.  So here's my question:  what is the mx scar supposed to look like at this point?  It's very, very angry looking, there's some black areas above the scar (last week it was cleaned up a bit, but it's still black), and it's still "leaking" just a little bit.  It's red, but not super red and hot.  Definitely a lot of bruising.   Do other people's mx look like just a straight surgical scar at this point?  Has my skin lost its integrity?  I'm so depressed about this and just obsessing that the "reconstruction" is not taking.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 03:38PM digger wrote: I saw the PS today for the first expansion and for him to take a look at the incision/scar.  Yes, as I suspected, he agreed that it's not healing very well, and the skin is just so paper thin that we both hope it holds.  He did put a tiny amount of fill in today but warned that next week he might have to drain some of it back out and then clean things up in an outpatient procedure.  I also have to slather it with anti-infective ointment to try to prevent another infection (I was already back in the hospital a week after the original mx with an infection).  I know these things happen, and I know I'm definitely not alone in things not going perfectly smoothly after a mx. It's interesting, however, in that I know the way the wound looks is definitely having an impact on my outward self-esteem.  This is an angry, very ugly, unsightly scar so in all honestly, it's really hard to even wrap my head around a new "breast" that will ever look appealing.  I know in my rational mind that absolutely no one can see the ugly wound I've got right now, so I'm trying to move past that, but it's hard.
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 05:20PM digger wrote: fogandroses, Thanks so much for your positive reply.  It's good to hear from someone else who has been through this and come out okay on the other end.  I too live about an hour from my doctor, so it's a pain to go back and forth, and I'm constantly trying to describe what the incision looks like over the phone.  I'm also incredibly squeamish when it comes to blood, cuts, etc.  My two boys knew never to involve me too much when it came to their various injuries and stitches, because I'd just pass out.  My having to deal with my own slowly healing wound now is just so hard, but, as you say, it will get better.  And, on the bright side, I'm now cancer free.
Posts.Title: Is my mx scar normal? digger BethNY

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2008 06:05AM digger wrote: I got my drains out last night at the hospital, and before going home, I said to hell with my surgical bra which I'd been wearing for the last week and tossed it into the trash.  I kept a camisole on and figured I would love not having the tight surgical bra on.  Boy, was I wrong.  Entire ride home ( a couple of hours), I sat crying to myself because I couldn't physically feel that bra anymore.  It made the numbness felt by my left side mastectomy seem like this hole in my chest.  I've still got my right breast intact, so it brought home to me how different the two were feeling.  The right one has its normal sag and lays on my skin.  Without that same feeling on my left, I felt this huge hole, I don't know how else to describe it.  As soon as I got home, I immediately put on one of the mastectomy bras I had bought before the operation, and it was a  relief to at least feel the band of the bra on my skin on my left side.  That somehow made it feel better, like I couldn't feel the sag on my right so I didn't feel my lack on the left as much.
Posts.Title: Can finally "B" Me mom2two kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2008 02:03PM digger wrote: Mom, Good idea about the massage.  I am hesitant to touch the site, but I imagine I would get the same benefit by massaging the site with my shirt on.  I was thinking about the one boob vs. two boobs on my short walk outside today, and I agree that by having just a single mx, it does drive it home a little more how different the feel and touch of one side is to the other.  Not that I have the right to complain, as I'm lucky my right breast is healthy.  The upside of all of this is that this Thanksgiving, I don't have to lift a finger preparing or cleaning up Thanksgiving dinner.  I'm trying to focus on other silver linings to this experience as well so I don't get too down on myself.
Posts.Title: Can finally "B" Me mom2two kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 03:53PM digger wrote: 2new1s, I'm so sorry you are having problems with infections.  I just was reading over this thread and wanted to let you know that it will be okay.  I too had a debridement a week after my unilateral mx (unfortunately, it wasn't nipple sparing because my DCIS was all over the breast) and then have just been holding my breath that the foob will be okay.  I'm three months out now, just got over another infection with the same weak skin, but it's still holding up and hopefully I'm on target for my exchange in just over two weeks.   It's really hard to get through all this.  The PS has way over expanded the one foob because he's going to have to get rid of the weak skin when he does the exchange, therefore he needs even more new, expanded skin.  I feel like I'm bumping into things with the one huge foob, compared to my natural A/smallB other breast.  I'm just not used to this huge thing!  And then, with these various infections, I have to keep cleaning and bandaging it, and I've got the weakest stomach for all of this!   But I know, in the end, everything will be okay and I'll be able to handle whatever is thrown at me.  Your debrided area will clear up, you'll get used to the new reality and the PS will be able to get those fills in.  Just keep your spirts up.  You're doing great. Take care.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 01:08PM digger wrote: I had heard of that study as well.  I think Susan Love has written about it as well.  I didn't talk to my surgeon about it, but I was aware that my surgery happened to be scheduled right in the second phase of my menstrual cycle (the two weeks before), so I was pleased about it.  I was also happy I wouldn't have to be dealing with my period right during the first few days or even week after my mx.  Just one less thing to have to deal with.  I'm not sure I can give you any advice for your own situation, however.  My thought is that, in all likelihood, it probably doesn't matter one iota in terms of recurrence when one has surgery.  I mean, I ate well all my life, have always exercised, you name it, and I still got breast cancer, so I'm not sure I put too much weight on any particular theories.
Posts.Title: Timing your surgery - did your doctors talk to you about that? agnes121 mocame

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 07:53PM digger wrote: BessB, My understanding (from my feverish reading when my mammo showed up with microcalcs) is that certain patterns of microcalcs are highly suspicious of cancer.  I can't remember, but I think it's the tight clusters of tiny, spiculated spots.  Most other patterns of microcalcs are quite common in women, particularly as you get older.  I, unfortunately, had tight clusters of microcalcs, and the radiologist and breast surgeon basically knew right away that they were an indication of cancer, hence they gave my mammo a BIRAD5 rating.  And, also unfortunately, they were right!
Posts.Title: I am soooooooo ANGRY!!!!! auroravtj mikita5

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 10:16AM digger wrote: I had a unilateral mx on Nov 20 and also had to deal with some necrosis.  I also went back and forth between should I keep it moist with the antibiotic and covering (which seemed to make it "goopier"), others said the moisture keeps the wound from healing, etc.  It was enough necrosis and dark black scabbing that a month later, in late December, the PS scheduled me for a procedure to take some of the saline out of my expander, remove the necrosis, then stitch the remaining good skin back together.  I was totally freaking out because it would have meant losing some of my fill (and the sooner the fills are done the sooner I can get this expander out!) and having to deal with a really unpleasant looking wound.  I'm such a baby when it comes to this.  Anyway, long story short, what I ended up doing was taking two showers a day, one in the morning and one in the evening, and letting the incision air-dry.  I just kept a light t-shirt over it so nothing rubbed on it.  By my surgery date in December, the PS said the scabbing looked dry enough to put the procedure off.  Yea!!  Now, a month later, the scabbing is still there, but it does seem to be continuing to get drier, and I'm super careful not to let the scab catch on anything, because you don't want anything coming off before it's ready.  My breast "mound" certainly isn't pretty to look at, but it's holding its own, and hopefully it will until my exchange in March, and at that time the PS will remove the necrosis part then when he's doing the rest of the work, all during anesthesia.   My one caution, and one I'm a little worried about but plunge forward anyway, is that the expander will get infected because deep down there probably is something going on with that affected skin.  But, so far, so good.  I trust my PS, so I'm just going to keep doing what I'm doing.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 07:58PM digger wrote: Wow, fea, that sounds exactly like mine in terms of size.  I just know for me, what worked was the showers, no ointment and letting it air dry a bit before putting on something really soft, nothing constricting.  Now, two months later, the black part is much smaller and really crusted over.  The PS, when I saw him this past Monday, told me to snip any parts of the scab that are kind of sticking out, so they don't get caught on something and just rip out before the skin underneath is ready to be "exposed."  I haven't been brave enough to snip anything, so I'm just being super careful when changing any clothes. I will say that I do continue to worry about the way the whole "foob" looks, in that it stil has that scab, albeit getting smaller, and, to me, seems pretty red where the new skin is showing.  But, as I said, the PS has seen it this past Monday, he seems okay with it, so I'm trying not to stress too much (much easier said than done!). In terms of daily activities, I have been careful not to bounce around at all, because for some reason I'm scared that will mess up the incision.  I know some people run and hike and do all sorts of regular athletic activities when they've got an expander in place, but I've stuck to the treadmill and elliptical.  Whether that's kept the incision from getting any worse, I have no idea. Oh, and in answer to your question, yes, the skin gets soft after the shower, and then it hardens up.  I do think that's perfectly normal, just like a similar scab would be on your knee, for example.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 03:54PM digger wrote: Francine, My thoughts are with you as well and am anxious to hear how things went with you today.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 03:25PM digger wrote: Actually, looking back, what probably did help me was a debridement I had about a week and a half after surgery.  I guess I blanked out on that because the plastic surgery resident did it in the urgent care center one Saturday morning, when I called the service because the wound was "leaking" and she said to come in.  And yes, I was on antibiotics throughout all of that, including a couple days of IV antibiotics (back in the hospital) about a week into it.   But I would say after about two or three weeks, I was off the antibiotics. Throughout all of this, the PS has continued his fills, for the most part.  I did keep asking him before each fill whether the incision would just burst and the expander come flying out (I think he thought I was crazy, but it sure seemed possible to me!), but, so far, it's still in there.  I'm not sure if it makes a difference that I'm keeping the mound small in the first place.  I started with 60cc at the time of surgery and am now at 300cc, which is all I really want.  I see the PS again in mid-February for a final look before March exchange, so we'll see what happens.  As I said before, it sure isn't pretty looking, but I guess it could be a lot worse.  I have a lot of confidence in the PS (he's at Sloan Kettering), so I'm just going with what he says.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy problem- Dying skin crusader1 NotVeryBrave

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 10:10PM digger wrote: That's a huge pet peeve of mine!!!  As soon as anyone hears I've had bc (and I really didn't tell that many people, but I guess word gets around and it seems like everyone and their brother knows), when I see them, they always start looking at my breasts!  I admit that I've always had body image problems and would rather sink into the woodwork than to have anyone looking at my body, so this new breast infatuation from those around me is really unnerving.  It's really going to be strange when I get my implants, because I'll be bigger than I ever was before (not because I want to, but I guess even the smallest silicone implants are bigger than my usual A cup).
Posts.Title: staring friends idaho 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2012 07:37PM digger wrote: I usually don't post anything on this board because, with early stage BC, I feel I could not possibly have any understanding or be able to provide any helpful support, having never been in your shoes. But, this thread appeared on the list of active topics, and I read it, and I have to say that it's important to understand that some boards on here can feel as if you're living in an alternate universe.  I'm talking about the topsy turvy world where coffee enemas, potatoes and furniture solvent cure cancer.  I suppose some people in that world, the early BC world, cling so tightly onto those odd ideas and opinions because they feel they need to.  They have such a vested interest in claiming to know exactly what caused their cancer, and exactly what is going to cure it and cause it never to come back again, simply because they're scared out of their minds.  There have been many posts on those forums that try to provide a balancing view, or, heaven forbid, a negative reaction to these "cures," but they're quickly batted away.  Particularly strident posters on that forum (for some reason, it seems to be taken over recently by a couple of very stubborn, determinedly head-in-the-sand people) just ban anyone that doesn't subscribe to their way of looking at the world. I am so sorry these ignorant posts have hurt you, I can see how they would.  There are many, many people who care about you and about everyone on the Stage IV forum.  Don't let anyone with foolhardy ideas on this complex beast of cancer bring you down. Take care.
Posts.Title: Know why I stick to stage IV! alesta29 banjobanjo

Posts.Content: digger wrote: I had a left mast a week ago.  Got out of the hospital after 2 days, went back in yesterday and today for an infection then was discharged home on stronger antibiotics.  So here's my question.  I'm sorry it's medical, but I don't want to keep asking what I think might be stuipid questions to the docs.  After a long ride home, I find my left side of my belly (kind of right above the hip bone) is really swollen and tingly, as is my upper arm.  The swelling on the left side of my belly is particularly prominent when I compare it to my right.  I did just have my second drain removed before I left the hospital, so maybe it's just extra fluid collecting?  Anyone else has had an episode like this? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Swelling on left side after left mast. digger burquie

Posts.Content: May 10, 2009 10:03PM digger wrote: I'm not sure about MRIs, but the mammos are classified into BIRAD 1 through 5, with 5 being the most likelihood of indicating cancer (I think it was 95%+ chance that the radiologist thinks it's cancer).  I unfortunately had a BIRAD5 mammogram rating, so I knew going into the biopsy that luck wasn't in my favor. I'm sure someone else will come along with exactly where that information comes from.
Posts.Title: MRI CLASSIFICATIONS mawhinney mawhinney

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 08:03PM digger wrote: Reported this one....if only the "cure" was this easy....

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 09:00PM - edited Jun 3, 2009 09:02PM by digger 37.  "I thought women with small breasts couldn't get breast cancer."  (husband of close friend) 38.  "So now you're back to new, right?"  (SIL after exchange)  39.  "I gave her itty-bitty tits because that's what she asked for" (my PS to my husband immediately after my exchange surgery, where I went from pre-cancer A to a post-cancer full C)
Posts.Title: 100 things never to say to a woman who has had a mastectomy: iwannabefree jillyG

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 09:28PM digger wrote: Baywatcher, I am three weeks out today from my mx and, like you, am not healing well.  I think the wound will likely be drained when I see the PS on Monday.  Similarly, I have become quite depressed as well as it is so hard to have to expose myself to this awful looking wound many times a day as I clean it.  And what's worse, is people keep telling me I should be ecstatic that the cancer is now gone.  But look what I have in its place?  It's like a grenade went off in my chest. I think it is highly unlikely that the chest wall is cancerous, I think that you and I just happen to have skin that doesn't heal too well.  It's just the luck of the draw, and we drew the short straw.  I would just keep bugging your surgeons.  I'm sorry that's all I can offer you, but I do feel for you and wish you well and many hugs.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: Not healing well baywatcher girlmace

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 03:34AM digger wrote: My heart is in agony for you Yan. I wish I could reach through this keyboard and somehow make it all better. You, your family, and Olga did not deserve this, and I ache for all of you.
Posts.Title: Olga Simkin Z"L leprechaun Bestbird

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 05:56PM digger wrote: Don't listen to your friends, listen to yourself.  My friends, particularly my mom, were "of course you're getting reconstruction, so you can just go on as normal."  I think it's easier for those around us to see that we look like we did before, it somehow makes them less scared for you.  But, life has changed, and we will be forever changed, whether we look like it on the outside or not.  So do whatever your heart feels is right for you, and you only.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 08:37PM digger wrote: I wish just one of my doctors, before cutting off my breast and then inserting this plastic shell in my chest, blowing it up and then sticking these permanent balloons in me, had taken just a moment to look me in the eye and ask:  so, how are you feeling about all of this?  That would have been really, really nice.  It's been one hell of a traumatic experience without one nod from them that perhaps it might have affected me on more than a just physical level.  To me, the operation may have been a success in their eyes, but they killed the patient.
Posts.Title: Dear doctor, I wish ... mawhinney 2frogs1princess

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 05:53PM digger wrote: I hope it's okay to post on this thread.  I just wanted to put in my two cents for what was right for me.  I'm very small breasted, so with a unilateral mastectomy five weeks ago, I did the tissue expander.  I'm too thin for the tissue transfer procedures, so the expander was my only choice.  My husband was fabulous and said he didn't care what I did, he just wants me healthy, nor did my breast surgeon care, she also just wanted the cancer out.  I must say that with just a little bit of a fill at the time of the operation, I came out of the OR with almost as big a foob on my left side as the natural one on my right side.  The only problem is that the foob is now where my boob used to be when I was 17, the other natural boob is in its 47-yr-old position.  I don't think I'm going to touch the healthy boob to make it even and will just wear a good bra when this is all over. So, I guess while it's obviously such a personal decision, I'm thinking that those of us with smaller boobs to begin with might have an easier time with reconstruction?  As an aside, the husband of a good friend of mine told her, when he found out I had breast cancer, that he didn't even think someone with such small boobs as mine could get breast cancer...ignorant, uh?
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2
